p: Evidence supporting human‚Äêinduced global warming and its effects on biological processes and biodiversity patterns are accumulating conspicuously (Parmesan, 2006; Pecl et al., 2017). This evidence comes from multiple sources, including studies on phenology (e.g., time of leaf unfolding events), shifts in the border of species' geographic ranges (Parmesan & Yohe, 2003) and those based on controlled experiments (Walker et al., 2006). Empirical evidence of the effects of global warming on biodiversity is so overwhelming that the number of synthesis of these impacts is increasing steadily (e.g., Ainsworth, Rosenberg, & Wang, 2007 and references therein; Halupka & Halupka, 2017).
